conclusion: Determine if the difference in speed between objects A and B is continuously increasing during the interval from 0 to t1.
Object A has a higher initial velocity compared to object B.
Both objects reach their maximum velocities at some point within the interval [0, t1].
Object A's velocity decreases more sharply after reaching its peak than object B's.
The difference in speed at any given time t is given by |v_A(t) - v_B(t)|.
The slope of the velocity-time graph represents the acceleration of the object.
If the slope of object A is steeper than that of object B, the difference in speed will increase.
If the slope of object B is steeper than that of object A, the difference in speed will decrease.
Initially, the slope of object A is steeper than that of object B.
As time progresses, the slope of object A becomes less steep, while the slope of object B remains relatively flat or slightly increases.
The difference in speed will start to decrease as time approaches t1.
The difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing.
Final answer: No, the difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
